title: Wednesday, 17th July 2019

BE11:26am

Saga currently trades on ~0.45x shareholder equity, implying the market is
applying a discount to the IFRS goodwill carrying value. To provide context, UK Motor peers (ex ADM due to its unique reinsurance arrangement) currently trade on ~2x shareholder equity.
Based on the current market cap, we estimate the haircut to goodwill to be ~60%. As shown in the table below, we arrive at a broadly similar figure (~65%) based on a run-off valuation approach.
While we acknowledge this is a crude calculation, we do believe it demonstrates market uncertainty around the ability of the insurance business to perform in line with Saga's expectations.

Galliford requested. Because we don't talk enough about UK construction and housebuilding.

Galliford Try PLC (GFRD:LSE): Last: 655.00, up 44 (+7.20%), High: 657.50, Low: 621.00, Volume: 743.49k
Ghazali morning all
BE11:32am

Trading update. Critical but stable, I think the phrase is.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Here's Peel Hunt to summarise.

BE11:33am

A straightforward year end statement which confirms existing profit forecasts and debt position should reassure the market. However, there is no new news on the contract settlement discussions at either the Aberdeen road or the outstanding £38m claim against the unnamed client. Forecasts are unchanged on the back of this update, as is our target price and belief that there is value in the current share price.

BE11:33am

They're shop.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Trading Update – The year end update was pretty much as expected and we see limited, if any, changes to expectations for FY19 or future years at this stage. Partnerships remains the best performing division while Linden has also continued to improve. Construction problems last year are hopefully behind it for now. Overall PBT (including exceptionals of c£70m) is expected to be in line with expectations of £113-£116m. Net debt was £60m at the end of the year with an average position of £187m – as previously guided. There is nothing new to report on the two key outstanding cash issues - the Aberdeen road and the unnamed £38m debtor that is refusing to pay. Galliford continues to work on a solution with both parties.

BE11:33am

Performance & Valuation – The shares have been soft in the last few months on worries about the scale of Construction issues and related pressures on cash flow. Ytd they are down 4% vs a 14% rally in the housebuilders. The shares are trading at book value and offer a dividend yield of nearly 12%. Any sort of sensible resolution to the two outstanding claims would materially improve the risk profile and share price.

BE11:34am

And Liberum.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Galliford Try's full year trading update says that management expects to report PBT (after exceptionals) in line with consensus (£113-116m, and Lib E £110m). Linden Homes has broadly maintained its sales rate and strong margin, Partnerships & Regeneration has continued to grow and Construction is no worse, with restructuring now complete. Net debt was worse than expected on a spot basis (at 30 June), but average net debt was in line with guidance (£187m). We do not expect consensus for 2019E or 2020E to change. Shares still look very cheap on 4.4x PER cal19E, yielding 11.5%. Re-rating should come through as Construction returns to stable profits (albeit at low levels) and the valuation becomes more appropriate for a housebuilder (which is the vast majority of the group) than a contractor.

Forester It pains me as a long suffering Saga holder that given their strong brand and the supportive demographics that they have miserably failed to find profitable opportunities!
BE11:34am

Hm.

11:38 am

You know Kerogen. Oil and gas specialist. Backs plays outside North America.

BE11:40am

Hurricane has a "don't panic, this is totally normal and fine and says nothing whatsoever about the prospects of our pipe working".

BE11:40am

On 17 July 2019, Kerogen announced that it had sold 110 million ordinary shares in the Company at a price of 46.5 pence per share. Following settlement, which is expected to take place on 19 July 2019, Kerogen will hold approximately 16.0 per cent of the Company's issued ordinary share capital. This residual holding will be subject to a lock-up period of 120 days, subject to customary exceptions.

Hurricane notes that Kerogen has signalled its continued support for the Company as it continues to be a major shareholder with a 16.0 per cent interest and a nominated representative on Hurricane's board of directors. Kerogen has participated in each of the Company's significant placings since April 2016 and this transaction represents approximately a quarter of its current holding.

Kerogen Investments No. 18 Limited is a Person Closely Associated (PCA) with Roy Kelly, a person discharging managerial responsibility at Hurricane Energy plc (as non-executive director). Accordingly, the below Notification of Dealing Form is provided in accordance with the requirements of EU Market Abuse Regulation (MAR).

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Morgan Stanley can summarise.

BE11:47am

Bottom line… We expect the market will be initially cautious to the H2 weighting in an otherwise unchanged guidance; however, taking account for the one off higher logistic costs in the first half in Clean Air, and timing of efficiencies in ENR we believe the phasing is not dependent on any market recovery as some might fear. FX is also now expected to be a 12m tailwind to PBT (previously 2m headwind) which should see numbers inch higher. JM this morning released a trading update ahead of its AGM, leaving its underlying guidance unchanged although noting that this mid to high single digit operating profit growth will be weighted to the second half. In terms of what is driving this phasing, JM cites two key effects. (1) JM now expects a weaker performance in Clean Air in particular in H1, as a consequence of higher logistic/freight costs to serve the strong growth in European LDV (share gains in diesel) given inventories now largely drawn down. This will normalise in H2 as the Poland plant is ramped up, but overall operating profit to be slightly down in Clean Air vs prior year. (2) This will be offset by greater efficiencies in particular in ENR as a consequence of the higher expected throughput at JM’s PGM refineries in H2 after the upgrade work is complete. Expectations in Health and New Markets remain largely unchanged.

BE11:47am

As can Barclays.

Punter @GBKrona very good point on GFRD, does look such good value, and @Tony Scott the divi is a factor.
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Our initial interpretation of today’s release was fairly negative. Changing the narrative around growth so soon after full-year results and deferring recovery into the second half generally doesn’t go down well in today’s market. But, having had time to discuss things with the company in detail, we feel a bit more comfortable. Hitting full-year guidance is far from a foregone conclusion but JM’s apparent resilience is a bright spot amidst a sector plagued by profit warnings.

tadam @Dec69 - Skeptic one day you will not be potentially dead, you will be just dead.
BE11:48am

..... which I guess is a reference to Umicore. Can't remember any other profit warnings, depending on how you define Matthey's sector.

BE11:48am

The biggest frustration for us was the change to guidance on EBIT growth in JM’s biggest division – Clean Air. Going from +3.5% (where consensus sits today) to ‘slightly negative’ isn’t that important in the grand scheme of things but investors are understandably nervous about this division given disappointing demand for cars recently and ongoing hesitation about the long-term future of diesel. JM was confident that underlying conditions haven’t diverged from their internal expectations. The company had intended to use inventory to cover orders until the new plant in Poland is up and running. In the event, downstream inventory levels were much lower than they’d anticipated which means the company had to deliver catalysts from their plants in Macedonia and Poland to customers very quickly. That, in turn, involved sending more by air and less by truck – which is quicker but much more expensive. That’s a very real cost to the business but shouldn’t recur once inventory is replenished over the slower holiday period. In fact, given how bad demand for cars has been in Europe it’s surprising that inventory wasn’t more backed up. Perversely, this unexpected issue should relieve any lingering concerns about a de-stocking event in future.

On consensus estimates, GAIN is expected to generate a pre-tax loss
of $29m in the year to December 2019 and currently trades on a 12% discount to FY19 forecast NAV. Retail revenue [associated with CFD and FX trading] makes up c80% of group revenue with futures revenue taking up the balance. Based on City Index accounts for FY17, revenue from CFD revenue represented around half of GAIN’s retail revenue with the other half predominantly from FX trading.

BE11:56am

We don’t have the breakdown of CFD and FX trading but in the latest Q1’19 trading update, GAIN reported a $17m operating loss in the retail segment and a $1m operating gain in the futures division. It is likely that GAIN’s CFD division underpinned the retail loss as CityIndex was already loss making in 2017 despite no leverage limits in Europe and better trading conditions. These negative conditions are highlighted in the GAIN share price which is down almost 40% since the start of leverage limits in Europe and low trading volatility.

are currently in place in Europe (and
potentially could threaten revenue in Australia). We don’t know what the
potential terms would be for such a deal but on the assumption that Plus500
could acquire this business (on a valuation discount), and acquire c155,000
customers, together with GAIN’s platform technology and the brands associated
with online trading, it could be an attractive preposition. Such a deal would
increase Plus500’s retail penetration and improve customer retention given
customer access to a more diverse range of traded products as well as attractive
trading features (such as charting, education and news) on a platform to enable
more trading. It would also diversify the offering with FX trading offered in
multiple jurisdictions including the US (where CFD’s are not available). In the
short term such an acquisition would not solve the current earnings uncertainty
but in the longer term Plus500 would strengthen its online retail presence.

VV75 thanks
BE12:06pm

Overall - a solid report with production across major product portfolio coming within the stated guidance range with exception to petroleum which came above guidance range driven by higher seasonal gas volumes and uptime due to planned shutdowns in the previous quarter.
Guidance for FY20 is strong with a step up in copper and iron ore and natural field decline in petroleum.
We expect the report to be taken positively in isolation but note that slightly negative China macro data is likely to be more important to the shares today.
Apart from the production results, the company has informed they are likely to take a US$1bn impact in terms of financials for FY19 primarily due to unplanned production outages and grade decline in copper and higher unit costs in coal.
Key points
Iron-ore: Iron ore production for FY19 (~238 mn tonnes) came with the guidance
nrange of 235-239mn tonnes and for 4Q19 was in-line with our expectations.
Copper: On copper production, production for FY19 came in-line with our
nestimates and was down 4% yoy.
Oil and Gas: On oil & gas, the numbers came slightly ahead of our expectations
ndriven by higher seasonal gas volumes and higher uptime.
Coal division: For 4Q19, both grades of coal came in higher than our
nexpectations driven by improved mining performance.

SoS Ha - looking at carbon ion - "Zap&Go is using carbon sourced from coconut shells"

red re battery tech. a lot of lithium and cobalt supply has been booked years in advance by the giants. they will need to work thru this and put it into cars before they entertain further new tech.
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE, the mill orders in China are worth a look at. These Analysts should really do on the ground work. the 40% consumption and price driving by China warrants speaking to them. It's not massively negative for the FE price but isn't great either.
12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

And Credit Suisse.

BE12:08pm

Challenging FY19 comes to an end: Reasonable operational finish to FY19
particularly in Petroleum and Iron Ore but YoY group production indicative of the
challenges faced during the year. Petroleum remains a stand out from our
perspective – beating guidance and showcasing the breadth of exploration and
potential development opportunities. Any calls for this business to be spun out near
term are premature in our view as it possesses exciting options over the medium term
to exact value. Iron Ore and Met Coal will again have material maintenance programs
in FY20, with the path to a sustainable 290Mtpa in the former and 49-54Mt in the
latter perhaps still some time off. All that said and like RIO yesterday, commodity
prices continue to overshadow the operational headwinds.
■ Soft FY20 outlook vs our previous assumptions: For all business segments
BHP’s production guidance for FY20 was below our prior assumptions. The numbers:
Petroleum 110-116mmboe; WAIO 273-286Mt (100% basis) which incorporates a
significant maintenance program at Port Hedland; Cu 1,160kt-1,230kt with just a 180-
205kt contribution from OD; Met Coal 41-45Mt impacted by major wash plant
shutdowns this quarter; and Energy Coal 24-26Mt as the focus continues on higher
CV products. We don’t discount the constant challenge in moving the dial productionwise
for a beast like BHP but slightly higher production growth in FY20, if all guidance
is met, will only go towards recovering the ~2% CuEq lost in FY19.
■ Additional takeaways: 1) FY19 unit costs to be towards the top end of guidance
(and above in Met and Energy coal), 2) Effective tax rate to be at the high end of the
33-38% guidance range, 3) US$260mn a part of further Samarco provisions flagged,
4) More gas discoveries in T&T with 3 wells in the Northern licences hitting
hydrocarbons, and 5) The second phase of drilling at Oak Dam progressed with
results currently being evaluated.
■ View: No change to TP or rating. EBITDA downgrades are ~3%-4% but adjusting our
LT ETR to 35% sees more punitive eps changes displayed below. The extent to
which BHP can eek out growth (ex-Petroleum) after FY20 will be of interest given the
FY19 issues and soft FY20 (vs our previous expectations) guidance. With far more
“self-help” in their corner, we continue to prefer it over RIO despite our Neutral rating.
